Award.AwardTitle: The Geometry of Banach Spaces and Its Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator will investigate the geometry of Banach spaces and its applications to many other areas of mathematics, especially logic and set theory. The techniques of Banach space theory provide strong tools for the study of operator theory, Fourier analysis and frame theory. More specifically, the investigator will study the factorizations of operators between classical Banach spaces such as the space of p-power integrable functions and p-power summable sequences. Intrinsic classifications of commutators of operators on Banach spaces with Pelczynski decomposition will be explored. The theory of Lipschitz p-summing, Lispchitz p-integral and Lipschits p-nuclear operators between metric spaces will be developed. Metric spaces with the Lipschitz lifting property will also be investigated. Necessary and sufficient conditions for Schauder frames to contain a subsequence that is a Schauder basis will be studied as well.

Banach spaces provide a framework for linear and non-linear functional analysis, probability, and optimization and are of fundamental importance in partial differential equations and mathematical models in quantum mechanics. Hence, the impact of advances in this branch of pure mathematics is far-reaching, extending across many areas of mathematics as well as to theoretical physics and multiple applications related to computer science and engineering. For instance, the study of Lipschitz mappings between metrics spaces has shown great impact on theoretical computer science and the uncertainty principle in quantum mechanics is ultimately a theorem about commutators of operators. The principal investigator will also support one graduate student on this project, and priority will be placed on selecting a qualified student from historically underrepresented background.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PI Zheng employed machinery of Banach space theory as well as
methods of logic and set theory to systematically study the structure of classical Banach spaces and to carry out applications to operator theory, approximation theory, frame theory and quantum mechanics. PI Zheng developed the theory of factorization of operators on $L_p$ spaces which contributes to the structural study of $L_p$ spaces. The PI answered Oja's conjecture negatively. The solution of Oja's conjecture pushed forward the explorations of one of the most famous open problems (the equivalence of BAP and AP for dual spaces) in the theory of approximation properties. The PI also solved an open problem of Bandyopadhyar, Lin and Rao which provided tools and motivation for developing approximation theory of classical function spaces. Characterizations of maximal ideals for the space of operators on certain classical Banach spaces produced significant applications to the theory of commutators and quantum mechanics. The solutions of the open problems of Argyros and Rosenthal once again showed the deep connections of combinatorics, logic and set theory with Banach space theory and exhibited the strong power of combining methods in these different fields.

The PI gave invited over fifteen talks (colloquium talks) at national or international conferences and workshops at Banff International Research Station, Hebrew University, University of Alberta, Texas A&M University, Washington University, University of Mississippi, Xiamen University,
Beihang University, Harbin Institute of Technology, Wuhan University and Wuhan Textile University. The PI published fifiteen papers at well known refereed math journals. The PI mentored three postdocs and has two another postdocs coming this December. The PI successfully attracted three graduate students to work in Banach space theory and is now serving as their advisor. It is worth mentioning that both students are underrepresented minorities. All these efforts made by the PI helped build the University of Memphis a center to attract and train students from traditionally underrepresented background.
